lines.Sulpicius: "I'm happy to see that you've both been very patient with me and my requests."

lines.Vitus: "Well, it's not every day that we have the ear of a governor."

lines.Volesus: "Even if the day was spent mostly hearing about all of the trouble you've landed yourself in."

lines.Vitus: "We've landed in our own problems too, Volesus."

lines.Sulpicius: "No, no, that's completely fair."
"I've complained far more than the both of you, but I'm much older."
"It leaves me with the impression that the both of you have seen a lot more of the world than you're letting me on."

lines.Volesus: "The both of us read many books."

lines.Sulpicius: "And here I thought that there must be quite a bit wanderlust in the both of you."
"Oh come now..."
"You cna't tell me that tromping the world is so bad when you're young and have no responsibility to tie you down."

lines.Volesus: "That just sounds like a polite way of saying we're homeless."

lines.Vitus: "As far as the life I've lived, I can't say the world has impressed me much."
"Just a lot of noise and misery."

lines.Sulpicius: "Hmm—"
"It doesn't sit well with me that a couple of men your age feel this dour about the world around you."

lines.Vitus: "It's hard not to feel down right now."

lines.Sulpicius: "I see..."
"A couple of thinkers at heart, huh?"
"Well, maybe I can help the both of you feel a bit at home?"
"Come along. I want to show you both something."
"If the both of you don't mind a small walk?

lines: (The governor leads us to a building tucked away and shrouded by trees in the noble district.)

lines.Sulpicius: "Much nicer than steam or a bucket of water, no?"

lines: (Heading inside, the governor asks the attendant for a private room for the three of us.)
(We follow the smell of citrus and clean linen into a room with a pool of clean water.)
(Eagerly, we disrobe into attire more suitable for the bathhouse.)

lines.Sulpicius: "This is where I go when the world feels too big and I need to think."
"I Hope that the both of you will consider coming here when the noise of reality becomes too much."
"You might just learn something new about yourselves if you share a little bit of what's good in the world."

lines.Volesus: "Ahhh— As far as I'm concerned, if this was the world it wouldn't be too bad."

lines.Vitus: "It does feel easier to open up and talk to somebody in a place like this."
"But that gives me an idea... maybe we could learn more about our travelling companions this way?"

lines.Volesus: "Just don't bring everybody at once if you do."

lines.Sulpicius: "That's a solid proposal, but you should keep something else in mind."
"People's capacity to talk with one another has limits."
"If you thought of your own capacity as currency... or tokens—if you will, then you may find yourself going bankrupt fairly fast."

lines.Volesus: "I feel that way almost all of the time."

lines.Sulpicius: "I'll help you work on that."
"Why don't you call for one of those companions of yours now and ask them something?"
"Exactly. Perhaps ask how they feel to be summoned? Or what it feels like to be ordered around."
"Behave, gentlemen."
"I will be using the bath for my own business, but if you have need of me do not hesitate to call."

lines.Volesus: "So Vitus, looks like it's just us now. I say it's time to relax!"
"Oh and if there's anyone you want to join us, just let me know."
